#ScienceMarchdc 
Go Best Friend! Dr. Janel Johnson

The Mathematics of the 'Hidden Figures‚Äô -Dr. Talitha Washington
.

#MathfestDC2017 #LookMaNoHands

If you are out and about in #DC and your feet are tired from the #ScienceMarch

Head on over to the #NationalMathFestival and support Dr. Talitha Washington and #HowardMath

It's poppin' AND dry in the Convention Center!

Dr. Talitha Washington is a mathematician in Howard University‚Äôs Department of Mathematics.
. 
She enjoys applying mathematics to understand and solve problems in biology, engineering, and physics

After completing her bachelor‚Äôs degree in mathematics from #SPELMAN she went on to become the first African American to earn a doctorate in mathematics from the University of Connecticut

She is active in increasing the participation of people of color and women in mathematics. Learn more at talithawashington.com

She is giving a flyyyyyy talk:

The Mathematics of the ‚ÄòHidden Figures‚Äô

What‚Äôs the mathematics that Katherine Johnson used to send John Glenn into orbit and bring him back safely?

Come and uncover the essential ideas created by Johnson during the Space Race.

She will also explore how other ‚ÄòHidden Figures‚Äô helped Johnson become a research mathematician in a in a racially segregated era.

#SPELMANalumni #DCiRepALLday #HiddenFigures #HandsFreeCodinglol

Artificial Intelligence in Retail @TrueFit

In retail, one of the latest trends taking the industry by storm is artificial intelligence (AI), or computer systems that can perform tasks typically done by humans, such as decision-making and visual perception.

AI uses real-time consumer data to help brands better understand shoppers‚Äô actions and decisions, such as the sentiment of a comment on a brand‚Äôs Instagram photo or the number of styles bought versus not

This in turn helps brands make better decisions when personalizing the shopping experience.

In order for AI systems to function properly, machine learning must first teach the computer how to absorb information by observing processes first, and then improving them

A recent article published on VentureBeat highlighted a number of companies that utilize machine learning to advance its operations, one being True Fit.

The article notes how True Fit‚Äôs technology helps brands observe how shoppers with certain body types buy as well as return particular footwear and apparel.

Machine learning technology strengthens consumers‚Äô True Fit profiles, which over time enables it to make smarter, more personalized fit and size recommendations.

Develop: üë†üë†üë†üë†üë†üë†üë†üë†üë†üë†üë†üë†üë†üë†üë† üë†The next generation of machine learning algorithms to help people find clothing that fits and flatters them @TrueFit

True Fit has built the world‚Äôs largest database of apparel, footwear, and consumer fit data in partnership with the world‚Äôs leading retailers, millions of consumers, and over 2,000 top brands.

True Fit's unique data set allows the creation of an individualized fit preference model for every user and a separate model for the fit of each garment.

This combination provides an extraordinary opportunity to develop algorithms that match users to clothing that they will love and keep.

#NSA

I wanted to pass along the info #HowardMath received about the S.P.I.R.A.L program.

In my day the program wasn't called this.  But I was essentially in this same program at Spelman College.  I may overuse this statement. But. It CHANGED my LIFE.

Without Spelman and funding through the NSA's SPIRAL program, I can't imagine my path through college and grad school having the same result.

What is SPIRAL:

The primary goal of the SPIRAL program is to provide a mentoring structure for underrepresented students and women that promotes active engagement in mathematics and statistics through an REU program

With a supportive structure, the participants will be encouraged to pursue and remain in mathematical sciences with the hopes that they diversify the talent pool of fully trained mathematicians/statisticians in academia, government, and industry.

Why SPIRAL:

I was 15 the first time anyone told me they were going to get a PhD in Math. I was in another summer program (link another time) with a brother named Billy. Hearing those words out of the mouth of one of my peers......was Insane

I thought he was insane. I looked at him like a Martian.  He might have just as well announced his plans to move to Mars.... I had never seen a Black person with a PhD in Math. I didn't realize it was even possible.

But he was serious. And he put the bug in my brain.

Long story short:

1. ‚ö´After High school. Billy chose Harvard. I chose Spelman

2. ‚ö´I received funding and support from NSA with Spiral, and realized Billy's dream.

3. ‚ö´Billy finished Harvard and attended Grad school. But NOT as a Math major.

4. ‚ö´ #SPELMAN where I finally saw a Black woman with a PhD in Math and everything else

LINK in Bio and Below:

#SPIRALworkedForME

LINK:

http://www.spiralreu.org/

PS. Senior year of college I did two summer programs. SPIRAL and EDGE. @theSameDamnTime  Gotta Share EDGE next. That was dope.

#Variance

Machine Learning Internship @Intel

LINK: In Bio and Below

If you run a #MachineLearning algorithm and it doesn't do as well as you are hoping, almost all the time it will be because you have either a high bias problem or a high variance problem

In other words either an underfitting problem or an overfitting problem.

Knowing which of these two things is happening would give a very strong indicator of the useful and promising ways to try to improve your algorithm.

How can we figure out if the learning algorithm is suffering from high bias or if it is suffering from high variance.

For the high bias case, that is, the case of underfitting, what we find is that both the test error and the training error are going to be high.

So, if your algorithm is suffering from a bias problem, the training set error would be high and you may find that the test error will also be high. It might be close, maybe just slightly higher than the training error.

And so, if you see this combination, that's a sign that your algorithm may be suffering from high bias.

If your algorithm is suffering from high variance, then the training error is going to be low.

That is, you're fitting the training set very well.  Whereas in contrast; your error on a test set will be much bigger than your training set error.

And so if you see this combination of values, then that is a clue that your learning algorithm may be suffering from high variance and might be overfitting.

By figuring out whether a learning algorithm may be suffering from high bias or a combination of both, gives us much better guidance for what might be promising things to try in order to improve the performance of the learning algorithm.

Suppose your training error is 0.10, and your test error is 0.30.  What problem is the algorithm most likely to be suffering from?

LINK:

http://jobs.intel.com/ShowJob/Id/1168240/Machine%20Learning%20Systems%20Intern

Answer:

High Variance (overfitting)

South African Airways: Youth Development @flysaa

#TSHWANE

South African Airways offers a variety of flyyyyyyy programs that positively prepare South Africa‚Äôs youth to take on a progressive career journey.

Geez. SAA combined all my favorite things: Pretoria, Flying, Math, Stats, Technology

Youth Development Programs:

1. ‚úàGraduate Program: a strategic initiative aimed at creating a talent pipeline for critical areas within our business as well as for the aviation sector in general

2. ‚úàInternship Program: The Internship Program may open the door to future potential working opportunities within SAA

3. ‚úàCadet Pilot Development Program: SAA is providing an opportunity to aspiring pilots to participate in the Cadet Pilot Development Program, a bursary award program aimed at assisting successful candidates with funding to obtain a Frozen Airline Transport Pilot's License.

4. ‚úàTechnical Apprenticeship Program: Matriculated with Maths, English and Physical Science (all subjects compulsory with at least E Symbol on Higher Grade or D Symbol on Standard Grade) OR minimum N3 Certificate with Maths and Engineering Science D Symbol

Please note that the Youth Development Program is aimed at providing successful candidates with tuition and practical exposure.

LINK: In Bio and Below

https://www.flysaa.com/about-us/leading-carrier/careers/youth-development

All of these things have a range of deadlines.  I believe the Cadet Pilot training program deadline is November 11, 2017

You might wanna call:

SAA

027-011-978-6044

#flysaa
